channel.title: CNBC International TV
channel.description:
CNBC is the recognized world leader in business news and provides real-time financial market coverage and business information to approximately 385 million homes worldwide.
With international headquarters in London, Singapore, and Abu Dhabi, CNBC International covers news and features from Europe, the Middle East, Africa and Asia Pacific.
Subscribe to CNBC International TV for the very best of CNBC's international programming, including top business news moments and award-winning original documentaries and feature series.
For real-time news updates from around the world, visit CNBC's website: http://www.cnbc.com
Subscribe to our other YouTube channel here: https://www.youtube.com/user/CNBCInternational/
Like our Facebook page www.facebook.com/cnbcinternational
Follow us on Twitter https://twitter.com/CNBCi

item.description: Chuck Robbins, chair and CEO at Cisco, speaks to CNBC's Karen Tso at Mobile World Congress in Barcelona, Spain.
item.title: Mercedes partnership just the beginning for Cisco's 'internet of things' growth, CEO says
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Nancy McKinstry, CEO at Wolters Kluwer, discusses the company's full-year results, her outlook for growth in 2023, and the resilience of the U.S. consumer.
item.title: Wolters Kluwer CEO: Share buyback of 1 billion euros planned for 2023
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: James Cheo of HSBC Global Private Banking and Wealth says it'll be a different situation for energy importers like Singapore.
item.title: Malaysia and Indonesia can benefit from higher energy prices, says HSBC
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Joseph Galli, CEO of Techtronic Industries, says it's been focused on cordless power tools for the last 15 years.
item.title: We've taken market share from our competitors for 14 years, says power tool company
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Derek Scissors of China Beige Book says the course of Chinese consumption should be clear by April.
item.title: Consumption in China may not be 'much better' than last year, says economist
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: C Vijayakumar of HCL Technologies says we will continue to hire more people in this quarter and next year.
item.title: We will continue to be a 'net hirer' in the industry, says tech company
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Nick McKeown, senior vice president at Intel's Network and Edge Group, discusses artificial intelligence and chatbots, cloud computing developments and 5G.
item.title: Dozens of varieties of chatbot will launch in coming months, Intel SVP says
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Amin Nasser, Saudi Aramco CEO, discusses the government-backed initiative, which will involve local companies such as Aramco.
item.title: Aramco CEO discusses Saudi government-backed program Shareek
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Benjamin Ho of the S. Rajaratnam School of International Studies discusses China's position on the Russia-Ukraine war and says it is playing the long game, though there are many other ways it can assist Russia.
item.title: China is 'certainly in no hurry' to provide lethal weapons to Russia, says assistant professor
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Stefan Angrick of Moody's Analytics says the Bank of Japan will probably dial back on yield curve control.
item.title: Bank of Japan will probably maintain monetary easing, but with a 'twist,' says Moody's
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Abhishek Jain of Arihant Capital says Adani's fundamentals won't run in the short term.
item.title: Adani Group's problems are 'largely a liquidity-driven issue,' analyst says
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Robert Hoffman of Citi Private Bank says the further the Fed has to go up from here, probably the more likely we are to see an actual U.S. recession in the second half of this year.
item.title: The clock is ticking on economic damage, Citi says
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: There will be a strong decoupling from China in tech and security, according to the CEO of Berlin Global Advisor Jan Kallmorgen, who doesn't advise investing in the country.
item.title: Analyst sees move away from investment in Chinese tech, security
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Jundong Zhang of China International Capital Corporation says that comes on the back of positive growth prospects and consumption may recover faster than expected.
item.title: We're 'modestly bullish' on China's A-share markets, says investment management firm
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Sri Mulyani Indrawati, Indonesia's finance minister, says there are some downside risks from exports.
item.title: We expect our economy to grow up to 5.3% this year, says Indonesia minister
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Matthew Eagan, portfolio manager at Loomis Sayles, discusses the investment outlook for fixed income.
item.title: Now time to get into bonds to add stability and decent yield: Portfolio manager
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Sweden has fulfilled conditions it agreed to at the NATO Summit in Madrid last summer, so it is time for the Turkish Parliament to begin the ratification process, Tobias Billström, Sweden's minister of foreign affairs, told CNBC.
item.title: Sweden NATO membership is happening, Swedish foreign minister says
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: David Schwimmer, CEO of the London Stock Exchange Group, speaks to CNBC about full-year results for 2022.
item.title: Revenue impact of Microsoft deal will be seen by 2025, LSEG CEO signals
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Ana Botin, the executive chair at Santander, speaks to CNBC's Charlotte Reed after the bank lifted its profitability goal on Tueasday.
item.title: Watch CNBC's full interview with Santander Executive Chair Ana Botin
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Suhaimi Ilias of the Maybank Investment Banking Group says Malaysia's budget this year is likely to retain the people-friendly tone of the budget that was tabled in October 2022.
item.title: Malaysia's 2023 budget: Expect another year of fuel subsidies, Maybank says
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: John Woods of the investment bank says India will continue to underperform for the first couple of quarters of 2023.
item.title: Foreign investors are making a 'pronounced rotation' from India to China, says Credit Suisse
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Jane Sun of the online travel firm outlines its policies with that aim, such as paying for egg freezing.
item.title: Trip.com Group's CEO discusses what the company is doing to support women

item.description: European banking stocks sink as fears around Silicon Valley Bank spread around the world. CNBC's Julianna Tatelbaum reports.
item.title: European banking stocks fall over 4% in early trade Friday
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Vincent Mortier of Amundi says it likes China A-shares, but not the very large names.
item.title: We've been positive on China for quite some time, says asset management firm
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Swedish Defense Minister Pål Jonson told CNBC's Silvia Amaro that giving Ukraine fighter jets is difficult, because Sweden needs them to maintain [its] territorial integrity.
item.title: Giving Ukraine fighter jets is 'difficult' because we need them, says Sweden's defense minister
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Jeff Fieldhack of Counterpoint Research says Apple is expected to be one of the few original equipment manufacturers to grow this year, along with Honor and potentially OnePlus.
item.title: Apple is leading in the 5G race, says research firm
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Danielle DiMartino Booth of Quill Intelligence disagrees with the Fed's use of time-lagged data to keep rates higher for longer. She argues that banks are signaling that the bankruptcy and default cycle has begun to unwind.
item.title: Fed Chair Powell will 'hide behind' data to keep rates higher for longer, says economist
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Telenor CEO Sigve Brekke tells CNBC how his industry is considering key themes such as the green transition, digitalisation, and security at the Mobile World Congress in Barcelona.
item.title: Telenor CEO: See resilience in the business as connectivity remains key amid inflation
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Lotfi Karoui of the investment bank says whether the U.S. Federal Reserve cuts interest rates in the first or second quarter of 2024 is up for debate.
item.title: U.S. Fed 'definitely' won't cut interest rates this year, Goldman Sachs says
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Ted Galen Carpenter of the Cato Institute says the problem is that the goals keep escalating.
item.title: Biden's Kyiv visit suggests the administration is doubling down on its support for Ukraine: Analyst
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Solvay's chief financial officer Karim Hajjar says what we can do is expect to navigate that.
item.title: Solvay CFO: We expect to maintain profitability, but we can't defy gravity
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Paul Gambles of MBMG Group says the Covid-19 pandemic revealed that many tech business models didn't make sense.
item.title: We've seen 'ridiculous levels' of overvaluation in U.S. tech, investment advisory firm says

item.description: Latvian President Egils Levits speaks to CNBC's Steve Sedgwick in Warsaw ahead of the one-year anniversary of Russia mounting a large-scale invasion of Ukraine.
item.title: Latvia president: Ukraine conflict cannot end until Russia moves back to recognized borders

item.description: Olivier d'Assier, head of applied research of Asia-Pacific at Qontigo, says China's regulators and the government are trying to make sure that the country is on target after last year's big miss.
item.title: It's 'all hands on deck' for China's 2023 GDP, analyst says
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Joachim Nagel, president of the Germany's Bundesbank and one of the ECB's more hawkish members, told CNBC's Annette Weisbach Wednesday that consumer price rises are set to remain stubbornly high.
item.title: Inflation will remain at a very high level, German central bank president says
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Mathias Cormann, secretary-general of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development, discusses the global outlook for 2023 and India's Group of 20 presidency.

item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Beat Wittmann, chairman of Porta Advisors, outlines what he looks for in equities and why the move from passive, long-only investing to total-return-oriented asset management is necessary.
item.title: 'New world order' requires investors to shift to active management, advisor says
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Zvi Eckstein, former deputy governor of the Bank of Israel, discusses demonstrations in Israel against the government's proposed judicial overhaul.
item.title: Israel's proposed judicial overhaul would be a 'complete revolution': Former central bank official

item.description: Beh Siew Kim, CEO of the real estate investment management company, discusses the outlook for the hospitality business and the changing habits of corporate travelers
item.title: People will still want to travel in the long term, says CapitaLand Investment
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Anthony Scaramucci, Skybridge Capital founder, says Donald Trump is unlikely to win the elections, but things happen in America that are unexpected.
item.title: Anthony Scaramucci says the U.S. needs stronger leadership and better direction
item.author: CNBC International TV

item.description: Travis Perkins CEO Nick Roberts argues he sees long-term fundamentals for growth in the U.K., as he outlines why his group is prepared to handle short-term volatility.

item.title: There's no recession at Holcim, CEO says

item.description: Tesla shares will go up to $260 apiece, according to Zacks Chief Equity Strategist John Blank, who spoke to CNBC's Squawk Box Europe after Elon Musk revealed his Master Plan Part 3 for the company.

item.description: Tim Baker of the bank says inflation isn't going away — it looks worse than where we were a few months ago, for the U.S., for Europe, for other places.

item.description: How the war in Ukraine ends will largely depend on the decisions made by Ukraine's allies with regards to Kyiv's ongoing weaponry needs such as long-range missiles and jets, Lithuania's President Gitanas Nauseda told CNBC.

item.title: Russia may not be positioned to carry out a large-scale offensive, says former U.S. diplomat

item.description:
Exercising command and control isn't necessarily the only way to get the best out of a team, according to Paul Marriott, President of SAP, Asia Pacific, Japan.
Instead, fostering an environment of trust and empowerment will pave the way for high performance, he told CNBC's My Biggest Lessons.
Trust is all about setting the standard. The standard you walk past is the standard you set, Marriott, who is also a youth rugby coach, said.
And by being empowered to set that standard higher, better outcomes will follow.
In a game of sport like rugby, the outcome is winning the game. There are steps and rules to get there, as long as they're followed, then drive to the bigger outcome.
This is just one of Paul Marriott's biggest lessons. Watch the video above for more.
---
